Sergiy Sydorenko: Our NATO membership is no longer a distant prospect.
Nine years ago, Ukrainian sociology showed that 67% of Ukrainians were against joining NATO, and only 18% of respondents were in favor.

After the Revolution of Dignity, the flight of Viktor Yanukovych, the annexation of Crimea, and the start of the war in Donbas, the number of NATO opponents began to decline, while the number of supporters, conversely, started to increase.
After the start of the full-scale war with Russia, Ukrainian sociologists recorded a record level of support for Ukraine's entry into NATO among Ukrainian citizens ‚Äì over 75%.

Despite support for Ukraine's entry into NATO and the assistance NATO provides in wartime, there is now much criticism of the Alliance and its member countries for untimely weapons deliveries, refusing to close the skies, and a reluctance to "irritate" Russia.

Additionally, there is a significant risk that Ukraine will be forced to abandon its aspiration for Alliance membership due to Russia's stance, if this can stop the war and Ukraine receives reliable security guarantees, including military ones.

In the new episode of the podcast "Cursed Questions," together with the editor of "European Truth," we discuss how the Alliance has been helping Ukraine since the Russian invasion, why NATO should be criticized, and why some criticisms of the Alliance are unwarranted, why our prospects for NATO membership are closer than ever in history, and why the security guarantees being discussed in negotiations with Russia could become a second Budapest Memorandum.

The international community continues to express shock and outrage following the emergence of evidence that Russian forces committed atrocities against civilians in Ukraine, while Moscow dismissed these reports as a "provocation.

Reports of Ukrainian civilians being killed, raped, and severely injured by Russian troops are worthy of condemnation," stated New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern to journalists in Wellington on April 4.
Russia must answer to the world for what they have done," she added, noting that her government will discuss additional measures to support Ukraine in its fight against the Russian invasion.
Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida called the incidents "a violation of international law.

The statements were made after reports emerged that hundreds of civilians had been shot and dumped into mass graves or left on the streets in the suburbs of Kyiv, in Bucha by Russian troops who had withdrawn from the area after occupying it for several weeks.
Photographs allegedly showing the bodies of executed civilians with bound hands shocked many and led to calls for increased sanctions against Russia and criminal prosecution of the perpetrators.
French President Emmanuel Macron stated in a radio interview on April 4 that there are indications that Russian troops committed "war crimes" in Bucha.
What happened in Bucha requires a new round of sanctions and very clear measures," Macron said, adding that additional sanctions should target Russian coal and oil exports.
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez stated that Russian troops could go so far as to commit "genocide" in Bucha.
We will do everything to ensure that those who committed these war crimes do not go unpunished," Sanchez said in Madrid.
Speaking on state television late on April 3, Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova dismissed the accusations as a "provocation.
She claimed without evidence that the United States and NATO "ordered" the images to discredit Russia.
In this case, it seems to me that the fact that these statements were made in the first minutes after these materials appeared leaves no doubt about who 'ordered' this story," Zakharova said.

Previously, the Russian Ministry of Defense also claimed without evidence that the images from Bucha were "yet another staging by the Kyiv regime" and that all Russian troops had left the city by March 30.
Moscow requested the UN Security Council to convene on April 4th to discuss what it called "a provocation by Ukrainian radicals" in Bucha.

On April 4, the Russian Investigative Committee released a statement announcing an "investigation" into accusations of Ukraine spreading "knowingly false information" about the actions of Russian troops in Bucha.
On April 3, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy accused Russian troops of committing "genocide" in the city and told Kremlin leaders to come to Bucha to see what their military had done.

The Briton who defended Mariupol in the ranks of the Ukrainian Armed Forces says they are ready to surrender to the Russians.
The Briton, who is a marine in the Ukrainian Armed Forces involved in defending Mariupol, told his friends and family that they would lay down their arms and surrender to the Russian occupiers.

Source: Twitter page of Aiden Aslin, a Briton who has served in the Ukrainian Armed Forces since 2018, BBC citing family members and friends of Aslin, Atlas News referring to the words of Aslin's friend who spoke with him.
Aislyn's literal tweet: "We received a message from him: 'It's been 48 days, we've tried everything possible to protect Mariupol, but we have no choice but to surrender to the Russian forces.

Details: Aislin served in the 36th Separate Marine Brigade of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, which is participating in the defensive operation in Mariupol.
BBC journalists contacted the mother of serviceman Ian Wood, and she confirmed that her son had informed her over the phone that they were planning to surrender.
Brennan Phillips, a friend of the soldier, also confirmed to journalists that in their last phone conversation, Aislin spoke about their unit's plans to surrender.
According to him, the brigade ran out of ammunition and food.
Journalists from Atlas News contacted his friend, who said that Eyslin's unit intends to surrender to Russian forces to avoid falling unarmed into the hands of the so-called "Kadyrovites" squads.
Social networks also circulated an audio recording of a phone conversation in which Aislin allegedly speaks with her American friend who plans to travel to Ukraine.

Aislin was a social worker in Newark-on-Trent, Nottinghamshire, but from 2015 to 2017, he went to fight against the terrorists of the so-called "Islamic State" in Syria.
In 2018, he officially joined the Armed Forces of Ukraine and took the oath.
Aislin's friends and relatives called him Johnny, while on social media he was better known by the nickname Cossack Gundi.

Last week, the Verkhovna Rada passed bill 7176, titled "On Monitoring Potential Threats to Ukraine's National Security in the Economic Sphere.

It is strange that essentially the only potential threat to Ukraine's national security in the economic sphere turned out to be... the location where the members of the supervisory boards of state companies and state banks hold their meetings.
The initiators of the bill believe that decisions made by the supervisory board of the state company in hypothetical Kyiv could somehow solve Ukraine's national security issues.
We are aware of many new risks for state-owned companies, but so far, no company has needed to physically hold a board meeting at its location.

The potential threat from such a law is clear ‚Äì it provides a perfect basis to "demolish" all the achievements in the difficult reform of state enterprises after the Revolution of Dignity, including independent supervisory boards, and then to establish manual control.
Such as it was before 2015.
Why do state companies need supervisory boards and who should be included in them?

Moreover, if one harmful bill "takes off" under patriotic slogans, others might follow tomorrow ‚Äì for example, the system of state procurement through ProZorro or the independence of the National Bank of Ukraine could be dismantled.
Much can be attributed to the war.
By the way, this initiative appeared even before the war and bill 7176.
Thus, on February 22, this standard was included in the comparative table of bill 5397.
Overall, the desire to dissolve the supervisory boards in one way or another has been circulating among some elected officials for a long time.
Not for the sake of criticism itself, but to show the possible consequences of the bill, let's analyze the arguments that explained the necessity of its adoption.
And then we will provide our suggestions on how to manage state-owned enterprises during the war.

The First Deputy Minister of Economy, Denys Kudin, explained the necessity of this innovation by the risks of losing internet and other communication means, which would make remote work of supervisory boards impossible.
In other words, the risk is that the supervisory board will be unable to make necessary decisions, which could paralyze the company's operations.
We agree that such a risk exists, but can it be prevented by relocating board members to Ukraine?

Imagine a rather cynical situation where independent board members (who make up the majority of the board) prioritize their personal safety over the interests of the company and refuse to travel to Ukraine.
In this case, according to the bill, they can be dismissed.
And then, most likely, this will lead to the loss of the quorum necessary for the supervisory board to make any decisions.
Instead, it will not be possible to quickly appoint new independent members to the supervisory board, as the law requires a competitive selection process that typically lasts 3-4 months.
Therefore, the solution proposed by Bill 7176 will most likely not prevent the loss of the supervisory board's ability to make decisions, but rather will lead to it!
Member of Parliament and author of the bill, Dmytro Natalukha, provides other arguments in its support.

In particular, he notes: "many enterprises, including those in the defense industry, currently need relocation," and therefore "it is hard to imagine that a person could, for example, discuss addresses and other sensitive information via Zoom from Vienna.
To begin with, in Ukraine, there are almost no state defense enterprises that have supervisory boards.
The Supervisory Board exists only in "Ukroboronprom," which essentially manages almost all state defense enterprises.
But even in "Ukroboronprom", according to the legislation, the supervisory board has quite limited powers, and all its members perform their duties on a paid basis.

The full authority in "Ukroboronprom" belongs to the CEO, who will also make decisions regarding the necessity of relocating any enterprise of the defense industry complex that is part of the consortium.
Moreover, this argument does not hold up to scrutiny also because bill 7176 does not introduce any changes to the legislation regulating the activities of state defense enterprises.
Mr. Dmytro also presents arguments on his Facebook page that can be classified as "emotional.

Such arguments usually have nothing to do with increasing the efficiency of state companies and state banks, but let's try to analyze some of them: "reputable foreign experts, at the mere mention of 'war', left Ukraine in 2021, yet they remain members of the supervisory boards of Ukrainian state enterprises with full salaries of several hundred thousand hryvnias, while Ukraine itself is actually suffering from the war.
Firstly, it is manipulation ‚Äì most of these board members have never lived in Ukraine and only visited periodically.
To say that they are "leaving Ukraine" is, to put it mildly, unfair.
Secondly, as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, both foreign and Ukrainian board members have long resorted to the practice of holding online meetings.
This tool has long been widespread in global practice, used in completely different fields such as business, education, medicine, and others.
One should also not forget that membership on the supervisory board is not a full-time job.
Typically, such people have other occupations, and electronic communication tools help them in this regard.
Thirdly, all these statements are read as claims directed exclusively at foreigners.
I wonder why Mr. Dmytro does not express identical claims against the members of the supervisory boards who are Ukrainians?
After all, they are also not located at the location of their companies.
Indeed, this is far from the first populist attempt by deputies to remove foreigners from supervisory boards, and the war is just a new convenient opportunity.

The United States, along with the G7 and the EU, are imposing new sanctions against the daughters of Russian President Putin, Russia's largest banks Alfa Bank and Sberbank, and are also banning all new investments in Russia.
This is stated in a message on the White House website.
Sberbank is the largest financial institution in Russia owned by the government, while Alfa-Bank is the largest private bank.
The sanctions will freeze any of their assets related to the US financial system and prohibit US citizens from doing business with them.
In addition, the United States will introduce a complete ban on new investments in Russia.
To this end, US President Joe Biden will sign a new decree that includes a ban on new investments in Russia by US citizens regardless of their location.
This move is based on the decision made by over 600 multinational companies to exit Russia.

The private sector output includes manufacturers, energy companies, large retailers, financial institutions, and other service providers such as legal and consulting firms," the White House statement said.
The third step of the new US sanctions involved restrictions against major Russian state-owned enterprises in critical sectors.
This will prohibit US citizens from conducting transactions with these organizations and freeze any of their assets within the jurisdiction of the States.
The Ministry of Finance will publish a detailed list the following day on Thursday.

The final part of the package includes a complete asset freeze of Putin's adult children, the wife and daughter of Foreign Minister Lavrov, as well as members of Russia's Security Council, including former President and Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev and Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin.
